comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: October 13, 1914 was the last day of the World Series, won by the Boston Braves in a four-game sweep. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1914_World_Series

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: This was apparently taken at an earlier time, though, when the Braves were playing at the Polo Grounds in New York. Gowdy was the hero of the Series that year for Boston. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hank_Gowdy

comment.author: 60329178@N02
comment._content: According to www.retrosheet.org/boxesetc/1914/VNY101914.htm, the last game the Boston Braves played against NY at the Polo Grounds was on 10/3/1914. Perhaps the dates on the negative is when the photographer developed and printed the image.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: ..or when Bain acquired the picture for its archive? Anyway, I see that the Braves were in New York for a six game homestand just before the end of the season, and that they had already clinched the pennant at that point (they ended up with a 10 1/2 game lead over the second place Giants. It would have been logical for Bain, a New York outfit, to order up photos of the Braves players then. www.retrosheet.org/boxesetc/1914/Y_1914.htm

comment.author: 60329178@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog] Yes, that was the year of the "Miracle Braves"...

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content:
artolog & swanq,

Thanks for the comments. I agree that the date of 10/13/14 on the negative may refer to when the photo was acquired by or copied by Bain, since it does show Gowdy at the Polo Grounds.  We will add a bit more detail to the record.
